items.title: After Rocket Attack, an Israeli City Seems Resigned to More in the Future
items.abstract: Intense fighting with Gaza has heightened concerns about safety in Rishon LeZion and seems to have renewed the sentiment among residents of the unlikeliness of a long-term solution in their lifetimes.

items.title: Union Attacks City for Refusing Role in Bus Strike
items.abstract: The union said the Bloomberg administration had rejected its offer to suspend the walkout in exchange for city officials’ halting plans for new contracts.

items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: Malian and French Troops Reassert Control in Key City
items.abstract: Soldiers filled the city of Gao on Monday after a firefight Sunday suggested that the quick French campaign against Islamist extremists in Mali was not over.
keywords: Mujao (Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa)

items.title: Plan Would Let State Take Control of City’s Teacher Evaluation System
items.abstract: If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the teachers’ union can’t reach an agreement, the proposal allows the state to establish an evaluation system for New York City’s educators.

items.title: State Challenges Plan to Revive City Opera
items.abstract: In a filing in federal bankrupcty court, the New York State Attorney General’s office raises several questions about a proposed reorganization of the defunct opera company.

items.title: Man Wrongly Convicted in ’97 Brooklyn Killing Settles With City and State
items.abstract: Roger Logan, who spent 17 years in prison for a fatal shooting, has reached agreements of $3.75 million from New York City and $2.975 million from New York State.

items.title: New York City Opera Will Return, and Soon, Under Reorganization Plan
items.abstract: The venerable opera company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in 2013, will be taken over by the NYCO Renaissance, which hopes to use the City Opera name by next week.

items.title: ‘City of Thorns,’ by Ben Rawlence
items.abstract: An intimate look inside the world’s largest refugee settlement, on the Kenya-Somalia border.
keywords: City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World's Largest Refugee Camp (Book)

items.title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘City of Thorns’
items.abstract: Ben Rawlence discusses “City of Thorns” and Janice Y. K. Lee talks about “The Expatriates.”

items.title: Judge Blocks New York City Law Aimed at Curbing Airbnb Rentals
items.abstract: The law was intended to prevent apartments from being used as illegal hotels. The decision could aid home-sharing services’ fights in other cities.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: An Indian City Bursting With Action
items.abstract: The present-day version of Chennai in South India dates back to only the 1600s, so a relatively youthful exuberance should not come as a surprise.

items.title: Are Electric Cars Only for the Rich? Sacramento Is Challenging That Notion
items.abstract: With funding from a surprising source, Volkswagen, California is making sure low-income communities have the chance to gain access to electric vehicles.

items.title: Kalief Browder’s Suicide Brought Changes to Rikers. Now It Has Led to a $3 Million Settlement.
items.abstract: Mr. Browder’s experience at the jail made him a symbol of unfair practices in the criminal justice system and led to a ban on solitary confinement for New York City youths.

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

items.title: Celebrating Black History Month? These 5 Cities Are Going All Out
items.abstract: Honoring all things African-American, with performances, river cruises, exhibitions and more, in Richmond, Va., Portland, Ore., Philadelphia, Cleveland and San Antonio.

items.title: Companies Finalize $26 Billion Deal With States and Cities to End Opioid Lawsuits
items.abstract: The first checks could be cut in April. The money — from the nation’s three major pharmaceutical distributors and Johnson & Johnson — will be used for addiction treatment and prevention.

items.title: Spurning Rebukes, Russia Escalates Attack on Ukraine as Refugee Ranks Swell
items.abstract: There was no sign of possible de-escalation on the sixth day of the invasion, as Russia appeared determined to toughen its tactics against a defiant neighbor.

items.title: The State of Fighting in Ukraine’s Besieged Cities
items.abstract: About two-thirds of Ukraine’s population of 44 million people lived in cities before Russia’s invasion began. Now many urban areas are in the cross-hairs of war.
